verses.text: While Israel was staying in Shittim, the people began to commit sexual immorality with the women of Moab.
verses.comment: The narrative highlights Israel falling into serious sin by mixing intimately with pagan nations. This serves as a warning for the importance of purity and faithfulness to God.

verses.text: They invited the people to the sacrifices of their gods, and the people ate and bowed down to their gods.
verses.comment: The connection between idolatry and immoral behavior is drawn here; by participating in these meals, Israel enters into fellowship with false gods, foreshadowing New Testament warnings against idolatry.

verses.text: So Israel joined themselves to Baal of Peor, and the LORD’s anger was kindled against Israel.
verses.comment: Baal of Peor represented a direct rejection of the LORD’s covenant. This act brings severe consequences, showing that fidelity to the one true God is demanded of God’s people, foreshadowing the call to spiritual faithfulness in the Church.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, “Take all the leaders of the people and publicly execute them before the LORD, so that the fierce anger of the LORD turns away from Israel.”
verses.comment: The judgment against the leaders reflects both the seriousness of leading others into sin and the need for public accountability in the community of faith. In the New Testament, leadership also bears great responsibility (Jas 3:1).

verses.text: So Moses said to the judges of Israel, “Each of you must kill those of his men who have joined themselves to Baal of Peor.”
verses.comment: Moses delegates the execution of justice, showing the importance of order and obedience within God’s chosen people.

verses.text: Then, one of the Israelites came and brought a Midianite woman to his family, in the sight of Moses and the whole congregation of Israel, while they were weeping at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: This bold act of defiance, done publicly, reveals a hardened heart and stands in contrast with the proper repentance and confession that God calls his people to.

verses.text: When Phinehas son of Eleazar, son of Aaron the priest, saw this, he rose up from among the congregation, took a spear in his hand,
verses.comment: Phinehas, being a priestly figure, acts zealously to defend the holiness of God’s people—his actions will later be described as meritorious (Ps. 106:30-31), reflecting the importance of priestly mediation and zeal for God’s honor.

verses.text: and went after the man of Israel into the inner room and pierced both of them through, the man of Israel and the woman through her belly. So the plague on the Israelites was stopped.
verses.comment: The intervention of Phinehas brings an end to the plague, highlighting the power of righteous intercession and atonement. This anticipates the idea that one’s holy actions can have a spiritual effect for others, later fulfilled in Christ’s perfect atonement.

verses.text: Nevertheless, those who died in the plague were twenty-four thousand.
verses.comment: Paul cites this incident in the New Testament as a warning against sexual immorality and idolatry among believers, showing its continuing relevance (1 Cor. 10:8).

verses.text: Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God’s direct address to Moses shows the continuing guidance God gives to his people through authorized leaders.

verses.text: "Phinehas the son of Eleazar, son of Aaron the priest, has turned my wrath away from the Israelites, because he was zealous with my zeal among them, and so I did not consume the Israelites in my zeal."
verses.comment: God honors Phinehas’ zeal, echoing David’s zeal for the house of God (Ps. 69:9). True priestly intercession preserves God’s people, hinting at the eternal priesthood established in Christ.

verses.text: "Therefore say, 'See, I give him my covenant of peace,'"
verses.comment: The covenant of peace is a perpetual gift, prefiguring later promises of a new and everlasting covenant (see Ezek. 37:26), which Christ fulfills for God’s people.

verses.text: "and it will be for him and his descendants after him a covenant of an everlasting priesthood, because he was zealous for his God and made atonement for the Israelites."
verses.comment: The perpetual priesthood promised to Phinehas points forward to the everlasting priesthood established in Christ (Heb. 5:6), and the ongoing role of priestly ministry in the life of God's people.

verses.text: Now the name of the Israelite who was killed with the Midianite woman was Zimri the son of Salu, a chief of a father’s house among the Simeonites.
verses.comment: Zimri's identification as a leader emphasizes that even God’s appointed leaders are not exempt from God’s judgment when they fall into grave sin.

verses.text: And the name of the Midianite woman who was killed was Cozbi, the daughter of Zur, who was head of a father’s house in Midian.
verses.comment: Naming both individuals underlines the seriousness of personal responsibility in leading others astray, a theme especially relevant for those in positions of influence.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God continues to reveal His will through Moses, showing that the revelation and guidance of God pass through the ones appointed for spiritual leadership.

verses.text: "Attack the Midianites and strike them down,"
verses.comment: The command to take action against the Midianites is rooted in the need to purge sin and protect the holiness of God’s people, echoing the biblical pattern of spiritual separation from evil.

verses.text: "for they have harassed you with their tricks, with which they deceived you in the matter of Peor, and in the matter of Cozbi, the daughter of a leader of Midian, their sister, who was killed in the day of the plague because of Peor."
verses.comment: The theme of deception and spiritual compromise is central here. God’s people are warned to be vigilant against influences that can lead them away from wholehearted obedience, a principle echoed in the epistles (e.g., 1 Cor. 10:6-12).
